title: Glen Finglas Walk Route

images.title: Colin Smith / Glen Finglas Reservoir
images.caption: Glen Finglas Reservoir. Looking south-west near Duart. The original Duart is probably now under the waters of the reservoir, maybe housed 4-5 families and had common grazing.

images.title: Colin Smith / Viewpoint in Glen Finglas
images.caption: Viewpoint in Glen Finglas. This unusual star on the ground is inscribed with lines of poetry from Sir Walter Scott. The view here is to the north-west, up the reservoir.

images.title: Gordon Brown / Approach to the bridge at Gleann Casaig
images.caption: Approach to the bridge at Gleann Casiag

images.title: Chris Eilbeck / Split Boulder, Glen Finglas
images.caption: Split Boulder

images.title: Chris Wimbush / Trail in Glen Finglas Woodland Trust
images.caption: Trail in Glen Finglas Woodland Trust

images.title: Concrete and colour by James Allan, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Concrete and colour of the dam at the southern end of the reservoir.

images.title: Gordon Brown / The Glen Finglas track
images.caption: Cows on the track on the eastern side of the water.

images.title: Chris Eilbeck / Toman Dubh
images.caption: Toman Dubh. A small island in the reservoir

description: Enjoy a walk along Glen Finglas Reservoir and Finglas Water on this lovely walk in the Trossachs. The glen consists of miles of attractive woodland trails, open heathland, rushing streams, waterfalls and challenging hill climbs. There's lots of wildlife to look out for including red deer, golden eagles and black grouse. You can park at the Glen Finglas car park to start your walk. From here you can pick up the waymarked trail to the reservoir. It follows the River Turk north before heading along the eastern side of the lake to Finglas Water. To extend your walk you can climb further into Glen Meann on the Mell trail. The circular trail runs for 15 miles and is suitable for mountain bikes and walkers. The cycling and walking trail along Loch Venachar and Loch Drunkie is also just to the south of the Glen. If you head west then you can visit Loch Achray and Loch Katrine .

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The track through the glen is also suitable for cycling. See the video below for a good view of the track. For more walking ideas in the area see the Loch Lomond and the Trossachs Walks page.
